ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include Chinese House Prices, Speeches from RBA Deputy Governor Debelle and BoC Governor Poloz
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US trade sources confirmed there was another deputy level trade talk via phone between the US and Chinese trade teams, while talks are said to be progressing as the two sides try to get a Phase One trade deal on paper. (Fox)

US and China are struggling to complete Phase One trade deal according to sources, with the sides still jostling over IP provisions, agricultural purchases and tariff rollbacks. Furthermore, US officials are said to be frustrated that China has not offered enough concessions to justify reduction in US tariffs. (FT)

China Customs have lifted restrictions on US poultry meat imports according to reports, while US Trade Representative Lighthizer and US Agriculture Secretary Perdue also announced farmers have regained access to China with US poultry exports expected to top USD 1bln a year. (Newswires)

Chinese Officials noted that they can always stop the agricultural purchases from the US if things get worse again, while Beijing reportedly wants to avoid a deal which is more favourable to US than China and wants agreement flexibility. (Politico)

Chinese President Xi said that restoring order and stopping violence is the most urgent task regarding Hong Kong at present, while he firmly opposes any external intervention. (SCMP)

US Senator Majority Leader McConnell said US senate needs to stand with Hong Kong whilst he hopes they can take action very soon, while US Senator Rubio tweeted that they have initiated the process of passing the Hong Kong Human Rights & Democracy Act by unanimous consent in the Senate. (Newswires/Twitter)

 

UK/EU

Brexit Party voters would rather 'spoil their ballot papers' than vote Conservative in the seats where Brexit Party Leader Farage has stood down his candidates, according to a lawyer who mediated talks between Farage and PM Johnson. (Twitter/Telegraph)

A Brexit Party candidate has pulled out of North Dudley which is the second most marginal Labour seat in country, while the Brexit Party candidate for Hove has also stepped down and other reports noted further Brexit Party candidates may also stand down. (Twitter/Mirror)

Ipsos MORI said 25% expect a Conservative majority and 33% expect a hung parliament. (Newswires)

ECB sources said policymakers told Chief Lagarde decisions should be made by consensus rather than a simple majority and that proposals should be distributed early and not front-run in public communications, while policymakers also disregard the idea of holding formal votes and publishing the tally. (Newswires)

German Finance Minister Scholz said the German economy is not in crisis and there is no need for stimulus now. (Newswires)

  • UK Retail Sales (Oct) Y/Y 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.7% (Prev. 3.1%). (Newswires)
  • UK Retail Sales Ex-Fuel (Oct) Y/Y 2.7% vs. Exp. 3.4% (Prev. 3.0%, Rev. 2.9%)
  • EU GDP Flash Estimate (Q3) Q/Q 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%)
  • EU GDP Flash Estimate (Q3) Y/Y 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.1%)
  • EU Employment Flash (Q3) Q/Q 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.20% (Prev. 0.20%)
  • EU Employment Flash (Q3) Y/Y 1.00% vs. Exp. 1.00% (Prev. 1.20%)

 

FX

SNB's Maechler said global economic outlook clouded by considerable uncertainty has pushed down on interest rates and the SNB remains willing to intervene in foreign currency markets to support economy. Maechler added that global interest rates could remain low for some time to come and the SNB's latest adjustment is designed to limit burden on banks. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks 2.219M vs. Exp. 1.649M (Prev. 7.929M). (Newswires)

OPEC Monthly Oil Report stated 2019 and 2020 oil demand growth remains unchanged at an increase of 980k BPD and 1.08mln BPD Y/Y respectively. unchanged from the prior report. The report also noted OPEC crude production in October increased by 943k BPD to average 29.65mln BPD (Prev. 28.49mln BPD), according to secondary sources in which oil output increased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and UAE, while production decreased in Ecuador, Angola, Iraq and Nigeria. (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea are reportedly not interested in meeting with the US according to KCNA, although other reports noted that North Korea said US Defence Secretary Esper's remarks on military drills is a positive effort for dialogue. (KCNA/Yonhap) 

 

US

Fed Chair Powell said the Fed does not yet see trade tensions spilling over into the broader economy and that trade tensions have contributed to manufacturing recession this year. (Newswires)

Fed’s Bullard (Voter, Dove) said Fed can reconsider whether to take back the recent insurance cuts if and when business adjust to new trade landscape, while he expects US job growth to slow,  forecasts growth of 2% or higher in the coming periods and suggested it is time for the Fed to wait and see the impact of the cuts made so far this year. (Newswires)

Fed’s Clarida (Voter, Neutral) said inflation expectations reside at low end of range he considers consistent with Fed’s price stability mandate, while he added there is no evidence wages are placing excessive upward pressure on inflation and believes the natural rate of unemployment extends to 4% and below. (Newswires)

Fed's Williams (Voter, Neutral) said the US economy and monetary policy is in a good place and that the Fed will adjust policy if there is a material change to the outlook. Williams added reserves are now at an ample level, while he added monetary policy should not get involved with the volatility of trade and Brexit and instead should take a longer view. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (2020 voter) expects the US economy to grow at a bit more than 2% in 2019 even though growth is sluggish and doesn't expect a recession in 2020, while Kaplan also noted the consumer is solid and he does not think inflation is going to run away from us. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that the stock market hit all-time highs again and noted great potential for the future and that companies and jobs are coming back like never before. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi said she wants to get the USMCA trade deal approved in the House this year, while it was also reported that a final USMCA package could be sent to Capitol Hill in the coming days following an earlier announcement from Pelosi who said a breakthrough is imminent. (Newswires/Fox)

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) opened lower after a downgrade at Maxim, citing disappointing survey data for iPhone demand. Goldman Sachs downgraded Kraft Heinz (KHC) to a Sell, and argued that profits are yet to floor with rising cost pressures on the horizon. Edison International (EIX) had a relief rally on reaching a settlement with public entities over 2017 and 2018 Californian fires. Netflix (NFLX) pared some of its losses and Disney (DIS) some of its gains after the latter surged on Wednesday following strong Disney+ subscriber figures. Xerox (XRX) and HP Inc (HPQ) were boosted by remarks from activist investor Carl Icahn, who spoke positively about the potential profit of the merger, and announced he had acquired a stake in HPQ. Tyson Foods (TSN) opened higher, albeit pared somewhat, post China pulling back on its ban of US poultry. American Outdoor Brands (AOBC) traded higher after announcing it would be splitting into two publicly traded companies. Google (GOOGL) rolled slightly towards the close as CNBC reported 50 AG’s are expanding their antitrust investigation into the company’s search and Android business, according to people familiar with the matter. Visa (V) also announced that the FTC requested information on whether its actions limited merchant’s choice. S&P 500 0.1% at 3097, NASDAQ-100 0% at 8258, Dow Jones 0% at 27785.

Yields were lower across the curve, with major curve spreads not deviating too much (+/- 1bps or so at settlement). The complex was rallying all day, reaching a peak after another article suggested that US/China trade talks are facing difficulties, but pared back as traders once again reasoned that there was little new substance in the report that shifts the narrative too much. US T-note (Z9) futures settled 14+ ticks higher at 129-11.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 14th November 2019: US/China struggling to complete Phase One trade deal
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities higher, Treasuries up, USD down, crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: US/China struggling to reach Phase One trade deal; Pelosi bullish on USMCA; Nothing new in Fedspeak.
  • COMING UP: EZ CPI (Final), US Retail Sales and Industrial Production, IEA Monthly Oil Report, US Refunding Settlement; RBA’s Debelle, BOC’s Poloz, ECB’s Mersh, BOC’s Lane

* USMCA: House Speaker Pelosi said a USMCA trade deal breakthrough could be 'imminent'. The Democrats had been seeking tweaks to the USMCA enforcement mechanisms for labour and environmental standards, and Pelosi's comments suggest that Republican and Democrats lawmakers are making progress on a agreement, which could be put in front of Congress by the end of this year, although this may be complicated by the House having to pass through government funding measures, amid impeachment proceedings, suggesting that time is tight.

* US/CHINA: China has lifted a ban on meat imports from the US, which had spanned almost five years. Reports suggested that this might pave the way for more than USD 1bln of poultry exports to China. US President Trump has made improving US exports of agriculture to China a pivotal part of trade negotiations, thus, auguring well for any potential trade deal. However, towards the tail end of the session FT reported that China and the US are struggling to complete a phase one trade deal, noting both sides are still jostling over IP provisions, agricultural purchases and tariff rollbacks. According to people familiar with the mater, Trump administration officials are frustrated that China has not offered enough concessions to justify a reduction in US tariffs on Chinese goods, a request China have been vocal about, even this morning reiterating cancelling tariffs is an important condition for achieving a deal. Another source noted China was absolutely delaying the truce with its approach, thus hampering the chances of reaching a final agreement in the coming days on the APEC summit timeline initially agreed upon by both sides.  Later, Fox citing US Trade Sources, said there was another deputy level trade talk on the phone between the US and Chinese trade teams, adding talks are progressing.

* FED: Fed Chair Powell's remarks at his testimony to the House Budget committee was similar to the comments he gave to the Joint Economic Committee on Tuesday. In the Q&A part of his testimony, he said the passage of the USMCA would remove uncertainty and be a very good thing for the US economy. Fed's Clarida (voter, neutral) said inflation expectations reside at low end of range he considers consistent with Fed’s price stability mandate; Clarida also said there was no evidence wage growth was placing excessive upward pressure on inflation, believes the natural rate of unemployment extends to 4.0% and below, includes the current rate of 3.6%. Fed's Williams (Voter, Neutral) said the US economy and monetary policy were in a good place, and that the Fed will adjust policy if there is a material change to the outlook. Williams repeated familiar arguments that ongoing uncertainty on trade and geopolitics is making businesses cautious, adding that if the US economy grows as expected, investment should grow as well; he also called on fiscal policy to play a more supportive role in a downturn. Williams also said that the Fed should not get involved with the volatility of trade and Brexit and instead should take a longer view. Fed’s Bullard (Voter, Dove) noted that the Fed can reconsider whether to “take back” the recent insurance cuts if and when business’ adjust to the new trade landscape. Bullard expects growth to slow, but forecasts growth of 2% or higher in the coming months (Note, the Fed’s median forecast for 2019 is 2.2%), hoping rate cuts will help with growth, adding he is hopeful improvements in productivity could push growth above 2%. Fed’s Kaplan (2020 Voter) expects the US economy to grow at a bit more than 2% in 2019; even though growth is sluggish, he doesn't expect a recession in 2020. Kaplan noted the consumer is solid and expressed his concerns on corporate debt. Fed's Evans (Voter, Dove) did not comment on monetary policy.

* US PPI: PPI firmed by a little more than expected in October, rising 0.4% M/M (0.3% expected) and the core rate at 0.3% M/M (0.2% expected). The trade services component drove the gains, reversing the fall seen in September. "Trade services measures margins for retailers and wholesalers, and the numbers are wildly volatile," Pantheon Macroeconomics explains, "behind the headlines, the most striking element of the report is healthcare, where hospital costs jumped by 1.0%, lifting the Y/Y rate to 3.7%, a six-year high." Pantheon is unsure how far this will run, but says that the combination of several years with prices rising slower than wages, amid a falling payment-to-cost ratio for Medicare and Medicaid, could prove a toxic mix." In terms of the core measure, Pantheon says it overall suggests markets have little to fear from inflation, "but healthcare accounts for about a fifth of the economy, and a sustained burst of rapid price increases in the sector would make a material difference to the core PCE inflation measure."

* US JOBLESS CLAIMS: Claims rose to 225k, the highest since June, and above the consensus 215k. Analysts suggested that the rise may be a result of seasonal issues around the Veteran’s Day holiday, although the California wildfires may have contributed. However, analysts generally do not seem too concerned that this marks the beginning of an upsurge, and the recent trend is essentially traversing sideways.

* HONG KONG: Hong Kong protestors were out in force for a fourth night this week, with the violence having escalated notably since a man was set on fire and another shot in the chest earlier in the week. There were some rumours that the Hong Kong government was mulling implementing a curfew, although these were quickly denied and labelled fake news. US Senator Majority Leader McConnell said that the US senate needs to stand with Hong Kong whilst he hopes they can take action very soon. The Senate is set to consider legislation that would force the State and Commerce Departments to certify annually whether Hong Kong is sufficiently autonomous from China to continue receiving unique treatment under US law, and that appears to be on lawmakers minds; US Senator Rubio said the process of passing our Hong Kong Human Rights & Democracy Act by unanimous consent in the Senate has been initiated.

* NORTH KOREA: North Korean nuclear envoy reportedly has voiced a willingness to meet with US counterparts if negotiated solution of issues is possible, reports Yonhap. Reports had noted that the North Koreans were encouraged by remarks made by US Defence Secretary on Tuesday, where he stated that the US is open to alterations in military activity on the Korean Peninsula to support North Korea diplomacy, which were seen as having a positive effect on dialogue.

* OPEC MOMR: OPEC forecast oil demand to grow by 980k BPD in 2019 and 1.08mln BPD in 2020; both forecasts left unchanged from the prior report. The report also noted that OPEC crude production for the month of October increased by 943k BPD to average 29.65mln BPD (Prev. 28.49mln BPD), according to secondary sources. Meanwhile, oil output increased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and the UAE, and decreased in Ecuador, Angola, Iraq and Nigeria.

* WTI (Z9) SETTLES USD 0.35 LOWER AT USD 56.77; BRENT (F0) SETTLES USD 0.09 LOWER AT USD 62.28. Weekly energy inventory data showed a larger than expected 2.2mln bbl build in headline crude stocks (contrasting with API, which showed a surprise draw) and that US production had reached a new all time high of 12.8mln BPD, putting the crude complex under pressure. Gasoline also showed an unexpected build of 1.86mln bbls, while distillates drew 2.5mln bbls, larger than the expected 0.95mln draw. Prior to the data, the crude markets had been on the front foot and had largely been bucking the markets more risk averse tone, with WTI Dec’ 19 and Brent Jan’ 20 futures advancing as high as USD 57.79/bbl and USD 63.21/bbl respectively. These gains were erased post data, with the two contracts falling to lows of USD 56.83/bbl and USD 62.28/bbl respectively. Around settlement, Russia’s President Putin said Russia should continue cooperating with OPEC, adding the cooperation should not only be on oil production cuts. Putin also stated Russia and OPEC can achieve a balanced global oil market without harming other countries.

* US T-NOTE (Z9) FUTURES SETTLED 14+ TICKS HIGHER AT 129-11. Yields were lower across the curve, with major curve spreads not deviating too much (+/- 1bps or so at settlement). The complex was rallying all day, reaching a peak after another article suggested that US/China trade talks are facing difficulties, but pared back as traders once again reasoned that there was little new substance in the report that shifts the narrative too much.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.1% at 3097, NASDAQ-100 0% at 8258, Dow Jones 0% at 27785

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.4%, Consumer Staples -0.1%, Energy -0.3%, Financials 0.1%, Health Care -0.1%, Industrials 0.3%, Information Technology -0.1%, Materials 0.5%, Telecommunication Services 0.3%, Utilities 0.2%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) opened lower after a downgrade at Maxim, citing disappointing survey data for iPhone demand. Goldman Sachs downgraded Kraft Heinz (KHC) to a Sell, and argued that profits are yet to floor with rising cost pressures on the horizon. Edison International (EIX) had a relief rally on reaching a settlement with public entities over 2017 and 2018 Californian fires. Netflix (NFLX) pared some of its losses and Disney (DIS) some of its gains after the latter surged on Wednesday following strong Disney+ subscriber figures. Xerox (XRX) and HP Inc (HPQ) were boosted by remarks from activist investor Carl Icahn, who spoke positively about the potential profit of the merger, and announced he had acquired a stake in HPQ. Tyson Foods (TSN) opened higher, albeit pared somewhat, post China pulling back on its ban of US poultry. American Outdoor Brands (AOBC) traded higher after announcing it would be splitting into two publicly traded companies. Google (GOOGL) rolled slightly towards the close as CNBC reported 50 AG’s are expanding their antitrust investigation into the company’s search and Android business, according to people familiar with the matter. Visa (V) also announced that the FTC requested information on whether its actions limited merchant’s choice.

* EARNINGS: Cisco (CSCO) had a strong quarter but its shares took a chunky hit after disappointing guidance for the next quarter. Walmart (WMT) beat on profit and raised its guidance, but revenue was a bit light, the stock surged on the open but reversed course throughout the session, with some desks noting that on the surface the EPS was positive, but was primarily driven by a lower tax rate. (NTAP) posted a strong EPS figure and had its PT raised across a handful of research houses. Viacom (VIAB) was firmer following top and bottom line beats ahead of its CBS (CBS) merger.

* UK POLITICS: Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party removed a few candidates for the upcoming election, with a key constituent being North Dudley, where political journalists highlighted that it would be an almost certain Conservative gain as 71% of the seat voted leave. Elsewhere, the UK has become a target of a legal case from the European Commission for not naming a new EU Commissioner. Also of note, The Telegraph reported that Brexit Party Voters would rather 'spoil their ballot papers' than vote Conservative in the seats where Brexit Party Leader Farage has stood down his candidates, citing a Lawyer who mediated talks between Farage and PM Johnson.

* FX WRAP: Havens were once again in demand, with traders citing concerns on growth (China IP soft, weekly claims tick up to highest since June, Germany avoids technical recession though has the weakest growth rate in the G5, Aussie employment was soft, while Japan GDP was also soft) and trade (reports of more ‘snags’ in trade talks); USDJPY beneath 108.50, XAU saw highs just shy of 1475, and EURCHF trades sub 1.09, raising the prospect of SNB intervention (as its policymakers have flagged up recently). There were also reports of some carry trade unwind after an afternoon risk wobble (the wobble itself proved fleeting). The buck fell, allowing the EUR to tick higher, though EURUSD ranges remain thin, with the single currency doing little to convincingly deviate too far from the 1.10 area. AUD was hit in the major FX space, after weak labour market data raises the prospect of RBA cuts, perhaps as early as its next meeting. In the UK, polls continue to see Tories out in front, the party with the only certainty about its Brexit agenda in the medium-term, allowing GBP to rally, though couldn’t manage to get up to 1.29. 

* BANXICO: The Mexican central bank cut rates by 25bps, as expected, disappointing a minority who were calling for a 50bps cut. However, the decision was not unanimous, with two members of the board opting for a deeper 50bps cut. Banxico noted that the balance of risks to growth remain to the downside, adding they will maintain a prudent policy stance, stating under the environment of uncertainty it will follow closely the potential pass through of exchange rate fluctuations to prices. The bank said bilateral US relations are among risks which could affect Mexican assets; Pemex and Mexico’s sovereign debt rating are other risks. The bank also expects the growth forecast for 2019 and 2020 will be lower than the previous forecasts.

States’ massive Google (GOOG, GOOGL) antitrust probe will expand into search and Android businesses, CNBC reports
content:
• Via CNBC
  • The 50 attorneys general investigating Google are preparing to expand their antitrust investigation into the company’s search and Android businesses, people familiar with the matter tell CNBC.
  • So far, the investigation, which is being led by Texas’ attorney general, has only explicitly focused on Google’s advertising business.
  • The development comes as politicians on both sides of the aisle, including President Donald Trump and Sen. Elizabeth Warren, increasingly tee off on Silicon Valley.

Putin also stated Russia and OPEC can achieve a balanced global oil market without harming other countries.

OPEC MOMR: OPEC forecast oil demand to grow by 980k BPD in 2019 and 1.08mln BPD in 2020; both forecasts left unchanged from the prior report. The report also noted that OPEC crude production for the month of October increased by 943k BPD to average 29.65mln BPD (Prev. 28.49mln BPD), according to secondary sources. Meanwhile, oil output increased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and the UAE, and decreased in Ecuador, Angola, Iraq and Nigeria.

PRIMER: Banxico rate decision due at 1900 GMT/1400 ET; expected to cut rates by 25bps to 7.50%
content:
• Ten of the 14 analysts surveyed by Reuters look for Banxico to cut rates by 25bps to 7.50%, which would be the third successive rate cut, given low growth (0.1% in Q3), stable inflation (3.02% in October, the middle of Banxico’s 2-4% range), rising unemployment (up to 3.8% this October from 3.2% last year) and a relatively stable MXN continuing to give the bank room for further easing.
  • A cut would also keep pace with the US Federal Reserve, which has also cut rates three times since the summer, with the US central bank now suggesting that its insurance cuts have concluded, and it has re-adopted its data-dependent stance, could also dissuade the board from taking more aggressive action.
  • Four analysts polled by Reuters look for a deeper 50bps rate cut, following soft GDP data in Q3 (NOTE: two of the bank’s five board members voted for a 50bps cut at the last meeting). However, most desks argue that the board will err against providing the market with any kind of dovish surprise. TD Securities argues that "increasing the easing trajectory would likely result in the market pricing in too aggressive an easing profile into Mexican assets (steps of 50bps instead of 25bps)... could degrade the relatively EM-leading, and peso-supportive yield that has been crucial in minimizing the external risks to inflation (via violent MXN depreciation) that have allowed Banxico to begin its easing process in the first place."
  • Other factors contributing to a more cautious approach by Banxico include; the risk of credit rating downgrades, the risk of another sharp increase in the minimum wage in 2020 and the risk of policy-triggered market instability following policy announcements by the Mexican administration, or the US ahead of the Presidential election campaign season.
  • Looking ahead, markets expect Banxico to finally “de-couple” from the Fed with a 25bps cut in December, after which the bank is then expected to pursue further easing. Money markets have priced in 75bps worth of easing through the year-end (including the potential 25bps cut this week). With real rates well within restrictive territory at near 4% combined with the benign inflation outlook, analysts at ING see the Banxico delivering a steady pace of 25bp cuts, until the policy rate drops to 6.5% at least.

Daily FX Wrap: Aussie rues bleak labour report and Kiwi empathises
content:
AUD/NZD

Little respite for the Antipodean Dollars, and Aussie in particular following an unexpected decline in employment that rekindled global growth jitters and expectations that the RBA may be forced to return from the sidelines and resume its easing cycle. Moreover, the downbeat data came just after softer than forecast Japanese GDP and ahead of Chinese IP and Retail Sales misses that undermined broad risk sentiment pending more updates on US-China Phase One and President Trump’s decision on auto tariffs. Aud/Usd has extended losses through 0.6775 and Aud/Jpy has fallen further from 74.00 where 1.6 bn option expiries ran off at the NY cut, but Aud/Nzd held just above 1.0600 as the Kiwi fell in sympathy and gradually unwound more RBNZ inspired gains in the run up to NZ manufacturing PMI and another post-meeting speech from Governor Orr (parliament testimony on the November OCR decision and deliberations). Nzd/Usd now nearer the base of a 0.6364-0.6418 range.

SEK/JPY/CHF

Relative G10 outperformers as the DXY continues to hover below 98.500 in narrow confines, with the Swedish Crown shrugging off ongoing statistical and data collation issues tarnishing jobs data, while the Yen and Franc both retain an element of safe-haven demand due to trade and geopolitical factors. Eur/Sek is capped ahead of 10.6900 in contrast to Eur/NOK hovering above 10.1000, while Usd/Jpy is still meandering between 108.86-57 and flanked by a Fib below 109.00 and bids/support at 108.50. Elsewhere, Usd/Chf and Eur/Chf reman sub-0.9900 and 1.0900 into a speech from SNB’s Maechler hot on the heels of dovish remarks by President Jordan.

GBP/CAD/EUR 

Very minimal deviation outside of prior parameters (Cable 1.2866-26, Usd/Cad 1.3270-45 and Eur/Usd 1.0990-1.1015) or last reaction to data from the Pound, Loonie and Euro respectively even though UK retail sales were worse than expected, Canadian new house prices were a bit firmer than forecast and German GDP defied consensus that would have meant a technical recession.

EM 

The Zar and Try remain divergent on supportive SA data vs ongoing Turkish-US tensions due to Syria and S-400/F-35 conflicts of interest/opinion, but Latam currencies are broadly depreciating alongside and in contagion with the Clp despite Chile’s Central Bank pledging to inject more liquidity and intervene in an effort to stem the tide and prevent a more intense capital flight.

subject: OPEC MONTHLY OIL REPORT (Nov): 2019 and 2020 oil demand growth remains unchanged; OPEC October crude production increased
content:
• For 2019, oil demand growth is forecast unchanged from the prior report at 980k BPD. In 2020, world oil demand is forecast to increase 1.08mln BPD Y/Y; unchanged from the prior report.
  • Demand for OPEC crude for 2019 at 30.7mln BPD, unchanged from the prior report. 2020 also remains unchanged at 29.6mln BPD. Non-OECD is assumed to be the largest contributor to oil demand growth.
  • OPEC crude production in October increased by 943k BPD to average 29.65mln BPD (Prev. 28.49mln BPD), according to secondary sources; oil output increased mostly in Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and UAE, while production decreased in Ecuador, Angola, Iraq and Nigeria
  • Preliminary data indicates that global oil supply in October increased by 1.67mln BPD to average 99.34mln BPD (Prev. 97.32mln BPD)
  • 2019 non-OPEC oil supply growth remains at 1.82mln BPD YY, unchanged from the prior release as “as higher-than-expected oil production in Canada, the UK and Kazakhstan, was offset by downward adjusted production data for the US, and Indonesia, among others.”
  • In 2020, non-OPEC oil supply is projected to grow by 2.17mln BPD (Prev. 2.20mln) due to lower than forecast production levels in 2019 which were carried over to the next year.
  • “2020 non-OPEC supply forecast remains subject to many uncertainties, including a continuation of investment discipline by US independent companies, pipeline constraints in Canada, drilling and completion activity levels in the US, unplanned outages, delayed start-ups and unexpected maintenance.”
  • OECD total products inventories fell in September by 9.7mln barrels MM to stand at 1.5bln barrels 33mln barrels above the same time a year ago, around 16mln above the latest 5yr average
  • The global economic growth forecast remains at 3.0% for both 2019 and 2020. Growth forecasts for all major regions remain unchanged for 2019. Risk remains skewed toward the downside, especially with underlying trade-related issues and associated uncertainties.
analysis_details:
• This differs from the EIA STEO which cut its 2019 world oil demand growth by 90k BPD to a 750k BPD Y/Y rise, raised 2020 world oil demand growth by 70k BPD to a 1.37mln BPD Y/Y increase whilst noting that production is set to exceed an average of 13mln BPD in Q4 2019, earlier than the prior forecast
  • It’s worth noting that this is the final OPEC Monthly release before OPEC and OPEC+ convene on December 5th/6th respectively in which the cartel will review its production policy set to end in March. Rhetoric thus far point to a continuation of the current pact, with sources dismissing deeper cuts with Saudi and Russia hesitant to bear the brunt of further reductions
  • Meanwhile, OPEC delegates previously noted that deeper cuts may be off the table as members are worried that the upside in crude prices from further cuts would be cancelled out by US production hikes. OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said this week that it is too early to say if further output cuts are needed.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 14th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are little changed in what has been tentative trade thus far on mixed US-China remarks, ahead of Powell part 2
  • China customs have lifted restrictions on US poultry meat imports, according to reports
  • German Q3 GDP Flash QQ 0.1%, avoiding a technical recession
  • Antipodeans underperform on poor AUD labour data, with the USD slightly firmer at present
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Initial Jobless Claims, Weekly EIA Inventories, OPEC Monthly Report (12:10 GMT), Banxico Rate Decision, Fed’s Clarida, Evans, Powell, Daly, Williams, Bullard, Kaplan, ECB’s de Galhau, SNB’s Maechler, RBNZ Governor Orr
  • Earnings: Walmart

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded somewhat mixed after a tentative lead from Wall St peers due to ongoing trade uncertainty and as the region digested several substandard tier-1 data releases. ASX 200 (+0.6%) was positive as tech and consumer staples led the early broad gains across Australia’s sectors and with abysmal jobs data supporting prospects the RBA may need to ease further. Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) succumbed to softer than expected Q3 GDP which disappointed hopes of front-loading ahead of the sales tax hike and raised questions regarding the Q4 outlook, although there were some success stories with Yahoo Japan the biggest gainer on news of a potential merger with Line Corp which also provided a tailwind for their respective parents SoftBank and Naver. Hang Seng (-0.9%) was the laggard and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) was indecisive amid the ongoing precarious US-China trade climate as President Trump commented that a deal is moving along very rapidly, although other reports suggested trade talks may have hit a snag over agricultural purchases. Furthermore, sentiment was also dragged by weaker than expected Chinese Industrial Production and Retail Sales data, as well as a decline in profits by index heavyweight Tencent and continued unrest in Hong Kong where protesters persisted with their new strategy of weekday disruptions. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher and broke through resistance at 153.00, with prices underpinned by the cautious sentiment, weaker than expected Q3 economic growth and firmer demand at the 5yr auction.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0083 vs. Exp. 7.0078 (Prev. 7.0026)

China stats bureau said the economy faces many external uncertainties and downward pressure continues, but also noted China will resist economic downward pressure and needs efforts to achieve full-year employment target. (Newswires)

Chinese Industrial Production (Oct) Y/Y 4.7% vs. Exp. 5.4% (Prev. 5.8%). Chinese Industrial Production YTD (Oct) Y/Y 5.6% vs. Exp. 5.6% (Prev. 5.6%) Chinese Retail Sales (Oct) Y/Y 7.2% vs. Exp. 7.9% (Prev. 7.8%) Chinese Retail Sales YTD (Oct) Y/Y 8.1% vs. Exp. 8.1% (Prev. 8.2%)

Japanese Economic Minister Nishimura said GDP data shows economy in gradual recovery and that they will closely watch private consumption. Nishimura added they must be vigilant of the impact from the sales tax hike and will prepare against downside risks from overseas economy, while he noted the effects from worsening ties with South Korea had a big impact on exports. (Newswires)

Japanese GDP (Q3) Q/Q 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.3%, Rev. 0.4%).

Japanese GDP (Q3) Y/Y 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 1.3%, Rev. 1.8%)

Hong Kong government is expected to announce a curfew for the weekend, according to sources cited by Global Times; However, SCMP citing a Government source state this is fake news. (Global Times/SCMP)

US

China's MOFCOM says cancelling tariffs is an important condition for achieving a trade deal between US and China; degree of tariff cancellation should entirely reflect importance of a Phase One agreement, sides remain in discussion an a Phase One agreement. (Newswires)

China customs have lifted restrictions on US poultry meat imports, according to reports. Subsequently, China's Global Times acknowledges earlier reports that China has lifted a ban of US poultry imports, which it says comes "amid the continuation of tradetalks, paving the way for hundreds of millions of dollars worth US meat export to China"; the US exported USD 390mln worth of poultry to China in 2014 before the ban. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK/EU

UK Tory party was said to offer a deal to the Brexit Party in which the latter would only contest 40 seats, although this was rejected by party leader Farage. According to reports, PM Johnson was prepared to put up “paper candidates” in opposition Labour-held constituencies to give an advantage to Brexit Party rivals, although Brexit Party Farage turned down the offer as they would prefer the Tories withdrawing their candidates altogether from the seats as they could still attract votes. (Telegraph) Note, Political Parties have until 16:00GMT today to confirm candidates for the upcoming general election.

ComRes UK election poll showed Conservatives at 40% (+3), Labour at 30% (+1), Lib Dems 16% (-1), Brexit 7% (-2) in survey conducted November 11th-12th. (Twitter)

UK Retail Sales MM (Oct) -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2%; Ex-Fuel MM (Oct) -0.3% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%)

- Retail Sales YY (Oct) 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.7% (Prev. 3.1%); Ex-Fuel YY (Oct) 2.7% vs. Exp. 3.4% (Prev. 3.0%, Rev. 2.9%)

German GDP Flash QQ SA (Q3) 0.1% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. -0.1%; Revised. -0.2%)

EU GDP Flash Estimate QQ (Q3) 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%); YY (Q3) 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.1%)

- EU Employment Flash YY (Q3) 1.00% vs. Exp. 1.00% (Prev. 1.20%); QQ (Q3) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.20% (Prev. 0.20%)

GEOPOLITICS

In related news, Turkey President Erdogan said Turkey expects the US to halt support for Kurdish YPG immediately, while he added that a US resolution on Armenian genocide is a shameful step. (Newswires)

A Gaza ceasefire has been agreed according to reports citing Egyptian and Islamic Jihad sources. (AFP/Twitter)

EQUITIES

Negative news regarding US/China trade talks, which have reportedly “hit a snag” over agricultural purchases and Chinese resistance to US demands for strong enforcement mechanisms, coupled with a disappointing data in the form of weak Chinese Industrial Production and Japanese GDP, saw major European bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 unch.) trade cautiously on Thursday morning. An upside surprise for German Q3 GDP numbers, which saw the country narrowly avoid a technical recession, was unable materially lift the DAX, which is weighed on by underperformance in a number of its heavyweights; Daimler (-3.0%) is lower on the news a shift into electric vehicles will negatively impact 2020 and 2021 earnings. Additionally, Merck (-1.6%) shares are under pressure despite upgrades to EBITDA and revenue guidance as the Co.’s Performance Materials unit saw adjusted EBITDA drop by 12.7% YY, while the Co. also warned that the economic environment could result in a moderate decline in semiconductors. Similarly, RWE (-3.3%) shares are also lower despite upgrades to EBITDA and revenue guidance after the Co. posted substantial losses for its generation’s unit. Later in the morning, European bourses received a short-lived lift on the news that Chinese customs have lifted restrictions on US poultry meat imports, albeit the move was fleeting. In terms of the sectors; defensives are amongst the outperformers, with Health Care (unch.), Utilities (-0.2%) and Consumer Staples (unch.). Tech (-0.5%) is also outperforming the market; Wirecard (+0.9%) is on the front foot following the news that the payments Co. has secured YeePay as a partner for global online bookings, with potential transaction volume from this is in excess of EUR 17bln per annum. In terms of other notable movers; Altice (+1.0%) and Henkel (-2.0%) are higher after earnings; the former reported strong EBITDA and revenue results while the latter confirmed its FY19 outlook. K+S (-2.1%) earnings were weaker as the Co. cut its 2019 potash production target by 200k tons and, subsequently, cut its FY19 EBITDA target. Ryanair (-1.0%) shares were pressured after the airline was downgraded to underweight at Exane BP. Finally, Bouygues (+1.4%) was bid after positive comments from its CEO, who said competition remains intense in the French telecom market, but less so than last year.

FX

AUD/NZD - The Aussie has tumbled to the bottom of the G10 table after a raft of sub-forecast data overnight, kicking off with Japanese Q3 GDP and extending through Australia’s October jobs report to Chinese IP and Retail Sales. Naturally, the big disappointment and shock was a decline in payrolls that was mostly down to a fall in permanent positions and contributed to an uptick in the unemployment rate, albeit in line with expectations. Aud/Usd recoiled from just over 0.6840 to sub-0.6800, while Aud/Nzd retreated further from pre-RBNZ peaks through 1.0650 and towards 1.0625 as the Kiwi holds up better vs a still rangebound Greenback (DXY meandering between 98.427-282) and within sight of the 0.6400 handle awaiting NZ manufacturing PMI and more from Governor Orr on the surprise decision to keep rates on hold this month. Note, Bascand underlined switch to wait-and-see mode last night, though left the door open to another OCR cut next February, if warranted.

JPY/CHF/GBP/EUR/CAD - All narrowly mixed vs the US Dollar, with the Yen and Franc maintaining an underlying bid and safe-haven premium even though China may have alleviated some trade jitters amidst reports of an ag snag by lifting its ban on US poultry. Usd/Jpy remains below a key Fib and pivoting chart support ahead of 108.50, while Aud/Jpy has retreated to around 73.80 amidst the all round Aussie underperformance noted above, but could pare some losses and revisit 74.00 given a hefty 1.6 bn option expiries in the cross at that strike. Meanwhile, Usd/Chf is back under 0.9900 and Eur/Chf near the base of a 1.0903-1.0864 band ahead of a speech by SNB’s Maechler that may well be used as another opportunity to espouse the mantra of sub-zero rates and proactive currency intervention to ensure that the Franc does not appreciate to excessive levels. Elsewhere, Sterling only saw a shallow and brief set-back when UK retail sales fell well short of consensus, with Cable back above 1.2850 and flirting with the 10 DMA, while Eur/Gbp is retesting 0.8555 stops, as Eur/Usd relinquishes 1.1000+ status recovered in wake of German Q3 GDP data beating forecasts that would have consigned the economy to a technical recession if confirmed. Note, however, the single currency is still finding support close to a 1.0993 Fib, while the Loonie is straddling 1.3250 again and eyeing Canadian new house prices to provide independent direction and a distraction to US claims and PPI.

SEK/NOK - Although Statistics Sweden has issued another warning about the reliability and sample size of the figures used to formulate monthly employment reports, the Swedish Krona appears to be taking the data at face value, as Eur/Sek probes below 10.6900 vs almost 10.7300 at one stage and compared to Eur/Nok that is elevated above 10.1000 and has been as high as 10.1300+.

EM - Some positive platitudes and constructive discussions, but no resolutions from the talks between Turkish and US Presidents has left the Lira under pressure and only a little off worst levels vs the Buck near 5.7800 in contrast to the Rand that has recouped losses on the back of significantly better that anticipated SA mining production and irrespective of persistent output disruption at Eskom. Indeed, Usd/Zar has pulled back sharply from 15.0000+ peaks to sub-14.8300 before bouncing.

Australian Employment Change (Oct) -19.0k vs. Exp. 15.0k (Prev. 14.7k). (Newswires) Australian Unemployment Rate (Oct) 5.3% vs. Exp. 5.3% (Prev. 5.2%)

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

- EUR/USD: 1.0965-75 (450M), 1.1000 (772M), 1.1020-30 (700M), 1.1040-50 (1.6BLN), 1.1055-65 (900M)

- AUD/JPY: 74.00 (1.6BLN)

FIXED INCOME

The latest Chinese concessions may only be paltry in the big scheme, but will appease some of the reported angst about sticking points that are apparently holding up Phase 1 of the trade agreement, and thus must be deemed as positive. Meanwhile, another surprisingly weak core debt sale, this time in the UK and perhaps even more perplexing given institutional demand for long-dated paper, has undermined Gilts that are well off best levels within 131.70-36 extremes. Similarly, Bunds have pared back from 170.87 and 10 year T-notes have drifted towards 129-00 vs 129-05+ as attention shifts to the US open a busy pm docket comprising data, more Fed speak including Chair Powell’s JEC part 2.

COMMODITIES – Note, OPEC Monthly Report to be released at 1210GMT

Crude markets are in the green despite the markets tentative feel, with a surprise draw in API inventory data last night helping underpin the benchmarks. Front month WTI and Brent futures advanced as high as USD 57.80/bbl and USD 63.20/bbl respectively, fresh highs for the week, although weak Japanese and Chinese data has since capped further upside. Looking ahead, official EIA inventory data will be published at 16:00 GMT. Fresh crude specific news flow has been light, although the OPEC Monthly Oil Report is due to be released at 12:10 GMT, which will be the final report before the Cartel convenes next month. In terms of metals; Copper has been on the front foot, pushing above its recent USD 2.6330/lbs to USD 2.6480/lbs intraday range, as the red metal largely shrugs off weak Chinese data. Tuesday reports of strikes in Chile appear to not have had a meaningful impact on the supply. Meanwhile, Gold is trading firmer; amid wider feelings of risk aversion, the precious metal has now reclaimed the USD 1470/oz handle.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks -0.54mln vs. Exp. +1.60mln (Prev. +4.26mln). (Newswires)

Meanwhile, Usd/Chf is back under 0.9900 and Eur/Chf near the base of a 1.0903-1.0864 band ahead of a speech by SNB’s Maechler that may well be used as another opportunity to espouse the mantra of sub-zero rates and proactive currency intervention to ensure that the Franc does not appreciate to excessive levels. Elsewhere, Sterling only saw a shallow and brief set-back when UK retail sales fell well short of consensus, with Cable back above 1.2850 and flirting with the 10 DMA, while Eur/Gbp is retesting 0.8555 stops, as Eur/Usd relinquishes 1.1000+ status recovered in wake of German Q3 GDP data beating forecasts that would have consigned the economy to a technical recession if confirmed. Note, however, the single currency is still finding support close to a 1.0993 Fib, while the Loonie is straddling 1.3250 again and eyeing Canadian new house prices to provide independent direction and a distraction to US claims and PPI.

SEK/NOK 

Although Statistics Sweden has issued another warning about the reliability and sample size of the figures used to formulate monthly employment reports, the Swedish Krona appears to be taking the data at face value, as Eur/Sek probes below 10.6900 vs almost 10.7300 at one stage and compared to Eur/Nok that is elevated above 10.1000 and has been as high as 10.1300+.

EM

Some positive platitudes and constructive discussions, but no resolutions from the talks between Turkish and US Presidents has left the Lira under pressure and only a little off worst levels vs the Buck near 5.7800 in contrast to the Rand that has recouped losses on the back of significantly better that anticipated SA mining production and irrespective of persistent output disruption at Eskom. Indeed, Usd/Zar has pulled back sharply from 15.0000+ peaks to sub-14.8300 before bouncing.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling strip maintain recovery momentum into retail sales and supply
content: In keeping with core counterparts, and pre-Liffe open indications, UK debt and STIR futures have overcome a few initial and very early wobbles to extend gains from recent lows amidst a broader and more pronounced retracement in bear-steepening spurred by dwindling optimism and risk appetite on the global trade front. Gilts are just shy of 131.70 vs 131.36 at worst and Wednesday’s 131.38 settlement and 3 month contracts are 0.5-1.5 ticks ahead compared to +2 ticks at best, awaiting the 4th and final piece of primary domestic data for this week in the guise of retail sales that are seen firmer than previous overall, but as always have the propensity to be erratic. Meanwhile, cash markets will presumably make room for long end issuance at some stage given the DMO’s Gbp2.25 bn 2049 offering some 60 minutes later.

Bunds: choppy trade post-German GDP amidst US-China trade and HK headlines
content: Unlike Wednesday’s in line early German data, preliminary Q3 GDP was firmer than forecast and prompted a warranted pull-back in the 10 year benchmark on the basis that the economy avoided entering a technical recession. However, Bunds subsequently rebounded to a marginal new Eurex intraday high alongside US Treasuries as MOFCOM reiterated its insistence on tariff rollbacks commensurate to the level of content and concessions in Phase 1 of the trade deal, and reports of a weekend curfew in Hong Kong circulated before the latter were denied. The core Eurozone debt future has settled down more recently between 170.63-26 parameters, just above yesterday’s session best and close (170.45 and 170.36 respectively). Ahead, more macro releases and several ECB speakers.

14th November 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded somewhat mixed after a tentative lead from Wall St peers due to ongoing trade uncertainty and as the region digested several substandard tier-1 data releases. ASX 200 (+0.6%) was positive as tech and consumer staples led the early broad gains across Australia’s sectors and with abysmal jobs data supporting prospects the RBA may need to ease further. Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) succumbed to softer than expected Q3 GDP which disappointed hopes of front-loading ahead of the sales tax hike and raised questions regarding the Q4 outlook, although there were some success stories with Yahoo Japan the biggest gainer on news of a potential merger with Line Corp which also provided a tailwind for their respective parents SoftBank and Naver. Hang Seng (-0.8%) was the laggard and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) was indecisive amid the ongoing precarious US-China trade climate as President Trump commented that a deal is moving along very rapidly, although other reports suggested trade talks may have hit a snag over agricultural purchases. Furthermore, sentiment was also dragged by weaker than expected Chinese Industrial Production and Retail Sales data, as well as a decline in profits by index heavyweight Tencent and continued unrest in Hong Kong where protesters persisted with their new strategy of weekday disruptions.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 14th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded somewhat mixed after a tentative lead from Wall St due to ongoing trade uncertainty
  • US-China trade talks have hit a snag over agricultural purchases according to the WSJ
  • Sentiment was also hampered overnight by weaker than expected Chinese Industrial Production and Retail Sales data
  • UK Tory party was said to offer a deal to the Brexit Party in which the latter would only contest 40 seats, although this was rejected by party leader Farage
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Flash GDP, UK Retail Sales, EU Flash Employment & GDP, US Initial Jobless Claims, Weekly EIA Inventories, OPEC Monthly Report, Banxico Rate Decision, Fed’s Clarida, Evans, Powell, Daly, Williams, Bullard, Kaplan, Norges Bank’s Nicolaisen, ECB’s de Guindos, Lane, de Galhau, SNB’s Maechler, RBNZ Governor Orr, supply from the UK
  • Earnings: Merck, Henkel, Bouygues, RWE, National Grid, Burberry Group, Walmart, NVIDIA, Viacom

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded somewhat mixed after a tentative lead from Wall St peers due to ongoing trade uncertainty and as the region digested several substandard tier-1 data releases. ASX 200 (+0.6%) was positive as tech and consumer staples led the early broad gains across Australia’s sectors and with abysmal jobs data supporting prospects the RBA may need to ease further. Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) succumbed to softer than expected Q3 GDP which disappointed hopes of front-loading ahead of the sales tax hike and raised questions regarding the Q4 outlook, although there were some success stories with Yahoo Japan the biggest gainer on news of a potential merger with Line Corp which also provided a tailwind for their respective parents SoftBank and Naver. Hang Seng (-0.8%) was the laggard and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) was indecisive amid the ongoing precarious US-China trade climate as President Trump commented that a deal is moving along very rapidly, although other reports suggested trade talks may have hit a snag over agricultural purchases. Furthermore, sentiment was also dragged by weaker than expected Chinese Industrial Production and Retail Sales data, as well as a decline in profits by index heavyweight Tencent and continued unrest in Hong Kong where protesters persisted with their new strategy of weekday disruptions. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher and broke through resistance at 153.00, with prices underpinned by the cautious sentiment, weaker than expected Q3 economic growth and firmer demand at the 5yr auction.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0083 vs. Exp. 7.0078 (Prev. 7.0026)

 

US President Trump said a trade deal with China is moving along very rapidly, while he also commented that he has been fully briefed on auto tariffs and will be making a decision fairly soon. (Newswires)

 

US-China trade talks have hit a snag over agricultural purchases according to reports which added that China is wary of putting a numerical figure on its commitment in the next potential agreement to avoid making the deal seem one-sided in Washington's favour. Furthermore, Chinese officials were said to have been resisting US demands for strong enforcement mechanisms and curbs on forced tech transfers. (WSJ)

 

China stats bureau said the economy faces many external uncertainties and downward pressure continues, but also noted China will resist economic downward pressure and needs efforts to achieve full-year employment target. (Newswires)

 

Chinese Industrial Production (Oct) Y/Y 4.7% vs. Exp. 5.4% (Prev. 5.8%). Chinese Industrial Production YTD (Oct) Y/Y 5.6% vs. Exp. 5.6% (Prev. 5.6%) Chinese Retail Sales (Oct) Y/Y 7.2% vs. Exp. 7.9% (Prev. 7.8%) Chinese Retail Sales YTD (Oct) Y/Y 8.1% vs. Exp. 8.1% (Prev. 8.2%)

 

Japanese Economic Minister Nishimura said GDP data shows economy in gradual recovery and that they will closely watch private consumption. Nishimura added they must be vigilant of the impact from the sales tax hike and will prepare against downside risks from overseas economy, while he noted the effects from worsening ties with South Korea had a big impact on exports. (Newswires)

 

Japanese GDP (Q3) Q/Q 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.3%, Rev. 0.4%).

Japanese GDP (Q3) Y/Y 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 1.3%, Rev. 1.8%) 

UK/EU

UK Tory party was said to offer a deal to the Brexit Party in which the latter would only contest 40 seats, although this was rejected by party leader Farage. According to reports, PM Johnson was prepared to put up “paper candidates” in opposition Labour-held constituencies to give an advantage to Brexit Party rivals, although Brexit Party Farage turned down the offer as they would prefer the Tories withdrawing their candidates altogether from the seats as they could still attract votes. (Telegraph) Note, Political Parties have until 16:00GMT today to confirm candidates for the upcoming general election.

 

ComRes UK election poll showed Conservatives at 40% (+3), Labour at 30% (+1), Lib Dems 16% (-1), Brexit 7% (-2) in survey conducted November 11th-12th. (Twitter)

 

UK RICS Housing Survey (Oct) -5 vs. Exp. -4.0 (Prev. -2.0, Rev. -3). (Newswires)

 

FX

DXY was relatively unchanged in a continuation of this week’s range-bound trade following inconclusive inflation data and after Fed Chair Powell provided nothing new during his testimony in Congress. The greenback’s major counterparts were also lacklustre in which EUR/USD attempted a breakdown of the 1.1000 handle and with a pullback in GBP/USD from resistance at 1.2850, while USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are choppy with a slight bias to the downside in the aftermath of the soft data. Antipodeans were the underperformers with AUD/USD leading the declines after the poor Chinese data and weak Australian jobs numbers which showed an increase in the Unemployment Rate, as well as a surprise contraction in Employment Change.

Australian Employment Change (Oct) -19.0k vs. Exp. 15.0k (Prev. 14.7k). (Newswires) Australian Unemployment Rate (Oct) 5.3% vs. Exp. 5.3% (Prev. 5.2%)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with mild outperformance seen in WTI crude futures following a surprise draw in headline API crude inventories which built upon the support from recent comments by OPEC Secretary General Barkindo who suggested potential for an upside swing in crude demand and a sharp reduction of supply estimates for next year. Elsewhere, gold continued to consolidate alongside an uneventful greenback, while copper was lacklustre due to the cautious risk tone and disappointing Chinese data.

 

US API Weekly Crude Stocks -0.54mln vs. Exp. +1.60mln (Prev. +4.26mln). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump said the Syrian ceasefire is holding very well and the Kurds seem satisfied, while added the US left troops in Syria only to secure the oil and that he will be talking with Turkish President Erdogan about a potential trade deal. In related news, Turkey President Erdogan said Turkey expects the US to halt support for Kurdish YPG immediately, while he added that a US resolution on Armenian genocide is a shameful step. (Newswires)

A Gaza ceasefire has been agreed according to reports citing Egyptian and Islamic Jihad sources. (AFP/Twitter) 

US

 

Yields were lower across the curve, with a bias towards narrower curve spreads, with the complex largely trading off of the over-arching risk tone from the APAC session and early European session, traversing sideways through US trade; US CPI, and a testimony from Fed chair Powell were digested with ease. There was some modest upside after the WSJ article on US/China trade talks hitting a snag, though the moves weren’t anything to write home about. US T-note (Z9) futures settled 11+ ticks higher at 128.28+.

Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said rate cuts this year have put monetary policy in a very good place, while Daly added she is open to the idea that risks are on the downside but noted that the Fed's stance is right so far. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia is subdued by data including surprise contraction in Australian jobs, softer than expected Japanese GDP and miss in Chinese Industrial Production and Retail Sales
content:
Asia equity markets trade somewhat mixed after a tentative lead from Wall St peers amid ongoing trade uncertainty and as the region digests several substandard tier-1 data releases. ASX 200 (+0.3%) is positive with tech and consumer staples leading the early broad gains across Australia’s sectors and with abysmal jobs data supporting prospects the RBA may need to ease further. Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) succumbed to softer than expected Q3 GDP which disappointed hopes of front-loading ahead of the sales tax hike and raised questions regarding the Q4 outlook, although there were some success stories with Yahoo Japan the biggest gainer on news of a potential merger with Line Corp which also provided a tailwind for their respective parents SoftBank and Naver. Hang Seng (-1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) trade subdued amid the ongoing precarious US-China trade climate as President Trump commented that a deal is moving along very rapidly, although other reports suggested trade talks may have hit a snag over agricultural purchases. Furthermore, sentiment has also been dragged by weaker than expected Chinese Industrial Production and Retail Sales data, as well as the continued unrest in Hong Kong where protesters persevere with their new strategy of weekday disruptions.

In FX markets, the DXY remains unchanged and has continued its range-bound trade following inconclusive inflation data and after Fed Chair Powell provided nothing new during his testimony in Congress where he repeated that the Fed's policy stance was likely to remain appropriate as long as incoming data was consistent with the Fed's outlook but added that noteworthy risks remain. The greenback’s major counterparts are also lacklustre with EUR/USD attempting a breakdown of the 1.1000 handle and with GBP/USD marginally pulling back from resistance at 1.2850, while USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are choppy with a slight bias to the downside in the aftermath of the soft data. Antipodeans are the underperformers with AUD/USD leading the declines to test 0.6800 to the downside after the poor Chinese data and weak Australian jobs numbers which showed an increase in the Unemployment Rate to 5.3% from 5.2%, as well as a surprise contraction in Employment Change by 19k jobs.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher as they sustain the prior day’s rebound to test resistance at 153.00, with prices also supported by the risk averse tone and following weaker than expected Q3 economic growth.

content:

Tencent (700 HK) - Co. Q3 net fell 13% Y/Y to CNY 20.4bln vs. Exp. CNY 23.5bln, rev. CNY 97.2bln vs. Exp. CNY 99.0bln, combined MAU of Weixin and WeChat 1.15bln vs. Prev. 1.08bln Y/Y, Adj. EBITDA margin 39% vs. Prev. 37% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Alibaba - Co. is planning around 500mln shares for Hong Kong listing and may offer stock at a 5% discount to its New York-listed shares. (Newswires/Nikkei)

Chemical - Chemical producers are reportedly to face inspections. (China Daily)

Infrastructure - China Cabinet said it will lower capital ratio requirement for some infrastructural investment projects. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Protests - Chinese Universities in Hong Kong will cancel all of their on-campus classes for November in Hong Kong, while there were also reports protesters vowed to stick to new strategy of weekday disruptions and have armed themselves with weapons inside the Polytechnic University. (SCMP)

Repos - Chinese press reports note PBoC may resume reverse repos this week citing analysts. (Newswires)

Geopolitics - Global Times tweeted that US warship movements are under the surveillance of the Chinese military, who will defend their national sovereignty and territorial integrity citing a PLA Eastern Command Spokesman. (Twitter)

Other News - China is planning to introduce unified regional GDP accounting early next year, in which the NBS will lead the unified accounting of regional GDP which is a shift from the current system in which local governments are in charge of the accounting related to their GDP figures. (Xinhua)

Trade

US President Trump said that the trade deal with China is moving along very rapidly. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi said growing protectionism is threatening international trade and investment, while he added it also leading to a global economic slowdown. (Newswires)

US-China trade talks have hit a snag over agricultural purchases according to reports which added that China is leery of putting a numerical figure on its commitment in the next potential agreement to avoid making the deal seem one-sided in Washington's favour. Furthermore, Chinese officials were said to have been resisting US demands for strong enforcement mechanisms and curbs on forced tech transfers. (WSJ)
